scripts/fdbshow                                 109     11     48     10    87%
Can you add a few more tests to boost the code coverage to above 90%?
Thank you!
@gechiang, I have updated unit tests and made some refactoring in fdshow script. Could you check the updates? Currently, fdbshow has covered by 100%.

Nice work!
Thanks for providing all variation of test cases to provide the code coverage!

Regarding `interface name <--> alias translation` that you are asking:
Its done in the function `def member_name(member)` 
   ```
def member_name(member):
        alias = member
        if clicommon.get_interface_naming_mode() == "alias" and member:
            alias = clicommon.InterfaceAliasConverter(db).name_to_alias(member)
        return alias

```
This function is called from filling the record:
 r = [vlan, data[vlan]['vlanid'], `member_name`(member), member_tagging(vlan,member)]

> Unit tests are failing. Please update unit tests accordingly and ensure coverage for VLAN with no members in addition to all other scenarios.

Test is in PR. Now it should PASS

@sujinmkang: We want to rephrase this message to be more user-friendly. However, we may need to either adjust the syntax here or in the `process-reboot-cause` parsing logic to parse the fields properly. Please provide your feedback.
@jleveque does this PR also wants to add the detail  kernel panic information or just inform the kernel crash as last reboot cause?

> @jleveque does this PR also wants to add the detail kernel panic information or just inform the kernel crash as last reboot cause?

Just inform that kernel panic was the last reboot cause.

@jleveque If the kernel panic happens after passing this line, I mean, if it happens during reboot, then there is still having a chance to miss the kernel panic? I think it will be good to have the core file directory or file name which is related to the kernel panic. We can add it from process-reboot-cause.

> @jleveque If the kernel panic happens after passing this line, I mean, if it happens during reboot, then there is still having a chance to miss the kernel panic? I think it will be good to have the core file directory or file name which is related to the kernel panic. We can add it from process-reboot-cause.

I see your point, but if a kernel panic occurs during reboot, it will be difficult (possibly impossible, e.g., if the filesystem is read-only) to leave a breadcrumb that we can use after booting back up to determine that a kernel panic occurred.

Also, technically speaking, if a user issues one of the `reboot` commands and a kernel panic happens during the reboot process, what was the cause of the reboot? Technically the reboot *was* initiated by the user.

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/28cb43cb42e3223cade2efa9a5f60542d97a89e7/src/sonic-host-services/scripts/determine-reboot-cause#L129
@yozhao101 please add the kernel panic case if you want to change the reboot-cause here.
And this too : https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/3a482ac38f1440fa0cbc00f621dc94ebb551757b/show/reboot_cause.py#L26

@yozhao101, @jleveque this change cannot be cherry-picked to 202012 cleanly, Is there a dependency needs to be cherry-picked?

I think this PR is depended on this one: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1199.

> Have a comment on [Azure/sonic-buildimage#6926](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/6926). The mock config db tables probably will need to be updated if that holds good

I’ll look into it a bit more. But we don’t need to change the db tables because the interfaces in config db is to hold the various lossless buffer profiles in buffer pg table, rather than the interfaces themselves.

> Have a comment on [Azure/sonic-buildimage#6926](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/6926). The mock config db tables probably will need to be updated if that holds good

Hi
I’ll look into it a bit more. But I think we don’t need to change the db tables because the interfaces in config db is to hold the various lossless buffer profiles in buffer pg table, rather than the interfaces themselves.

> > Have a comment on [Azure/sonic-buildimage#6926](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/6926). The mock config db tables probably will need to be updated if that holds good
> 
> I’ll look into it a bit more. But we don’t need to change the db tables because the interfaces in config db is to hold the various lossless buffer profiles in buffer pg table, rather than the interfaces themselves.
> 
> > Have a comment on [Azure/sonic-buildimage#6926](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/6926). The mock config db tables probably will need to be updated if that holds good
> 
> Hi
> I’ll look into it a bit more. But I think we don’t need to change the db tables because the interfaces in config db is to hold the various lossless buffer profiles in buffer pg table, rather than the interfaces themselves.

Wouldn't the interfaces in the BUFFER_PG table change?

> > Hi
> > I’ll look into it a bit more. But I think we don’t need to change the db tables because the interfaces in config db is to hold the various lossless buffer profiles in buffer pg table, rather than the interfaces themselves.
> 
> Wouldn't the interfaces in the BUFFER_PG table change?

Hi @neethajohn ,
Not really.
The DB migrator has a generic logic to check whether the buffer configuration aligns with the default one. For `BUFFER_PG` table, it checks whether:
- the PGs are default ones: PG 0 for lossy and PG 3-4 for lossless
- the `profile` aligns with the port's speed and cable length

But it doesn't check whether the port configuration, including its speed, cable length, etc., aligns with the default value according to the SKU configuration. In addition, we configured the interfaces with different (`speed`, `cable length`) tuple in order to verify all possible compositions in `pg_profile_lookup.ini`.
To make it simple, we have some config DB files for different SKUs sharing the same port configuration.

@Junchao-Mellanox  Please create PR for 201911.

@qiluo-msft
Hi @abdosi and @qiluo-msft , I suppose this PR is not necessary for 201911. @stephenxs, please correct me if i am wrong.

> Hi @abdosi and @qiluo-msft , I suppose this PR is not necessary for 201911. @stephenxs, please correct me if i am wrong.

You are correct.
@abdosi @qiluo-msft @liat-grozovik 
We don't need to back-port this PR to 201911 because:
 - The motivation of this PR is to support upgrading from older versions to the 202012/master for D40C8S8
 - There isn't a flow in which the device is upgraded from a version older than 201911 to 201911 since 201911 is the first version supporting D40C8S8

Hence, we don't need to back-port it to 201911.

Dear @prsunny,

The issue https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/894 is pretty similar to https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/6367. Could I ask you to check could we solve the issue with this changes?
Based on your configuration, IMO, the FDB should be on the 'untagged' vlan, i.e Vlan40 as a port can be untagged in only one Vlan. Displaying as "untagged" looks to be incomplete.

Dear @prsunny,

Actually, the system has two different FDB entries for the same MAC address in case with tagged Vlan: entry, linked to Vlan40 and entry with link to default Vlan(I have updated PR overview comment. Now, there are 3 FDB entries, 2 of which belongs to the same MAC address). 

>Displaying as "untagged" looks to be incomplete.
I am sorry, could you clarify what did you mean with this comment? Are you proposing to mark FDB entries with default Vlan somehow like this: 
```
  No.  Vlan          MacAddress         Port             Type
-----  ------------  -----------------  ---------------  -------
    1  (40)Untagged  24:8A:07:EE:4D:E1  PortChannel0002  Dynamic
```

In the first place, how is fdb learnt on a non-configured Vlan? During initialization all ports are removed from default vlan. Secondly, providing the info as "untagged" can have implications. For. e.g, how can user flush this entry as there is no Vlan associated.

@prsunny, I was wrong in my understanding of the situation. In fact, when you link Ethernet port with tagged Vlan, as in my case, the port could either receive tagged and untagged traffic. In tagged case, the traffic routes to the Vlan, but in untagged case the traffic will be automatically assigned to Native Vlan and routed there. For this traffic, the FDB entry with default Vlan is being created(and marked as Untagged in `show mac` with my solution). I could not see any configurational mechanisms for native Vlans in the system and I presume that the untagged traffic in this case is currently being dropped by the system. Could you correct me if it not so?
Maybe, it would be better not to show FDB entries with default Vlan assigned, as the system behave with the traffic as with trash?

Answering on your questions:
> how is fdb learnt on a non-configured Vlan? During initialization all ports are removed from default vlan.:

The system does not create FDB entries till you link the port with a Vlan.
> providing the info as "untagged" can have implications. For. e.g, how can user flush this entry as there is no Vlan associated.

I agree with you. According to my proposition above, maybe, we could skip such FDB entries and not to show them with `show mac`, or, we could mark them not as `Untagged`, but, for example, as `Native `or something similar? But, IMO, skipping would be better.
@prsunny, could I ask you to pay some attention on my last comment?

@maksymbelei95 When You add a port to a vlan as untagged, It means that any untagged packet packets entering that port should be part of that VLAN (Bridge domain).  Any interface can be an "untagged" member of only 1 Bridging domain (VLAN).
For example, you configure a new VLAN 50 and then add  port1 to it as "untagged"  and also add port2 as tagged.
If now you send an untagged packet with unknown destination MAC through port1, it will be flooded to port2 only.  If you add port3 to VLAN 50 and send the same packet, it will now be flooded to both port2 and port3. This is because port1, 2, and 3 are all part of the same "bridging domain" that was configured under VLAN 50.
If you send an unknown tagged packet through port2, it will be flooded through port1 and port3.  When the packet exit out of port1, it should be untagged.
So it does not make sense to have a "show mac" to display "untagged" under the VLAN column.  As @prsunny mentioned, it would not help the user to understand which VLAN (bridging domain) that mac belongs to.  The purpose of show mac is to list out MACs learnt for each of the VLAN.  In my opinion "show mac" output should not care whether it was learnt over an "untagged" or "tagged" interface.  This is because we already have the interface displayed as part of the "show mac" and we can find out if that interface was part of the "tagged"/"untagged" membership of that VLAN already...
Also, if a VLAN is not configured and thus no port can be part of it, there should not be any MAC learnt as there are no "bridging domain" to classify it to.  In fact, SAI Shall not be announcing such MAC learning event.  If it does, then it is a SAI issue that needs to be fixed.
@gechiang, @prsunny, sorry for delayed response. Thank you for explanation. I have updated the PR. Now, FDB entries, linked to default Vlan, just will not be displayed for user.

Hi Liat,

I looked at the changes, and they are fine. However, I have a comment. It
seems we are having an implicit assumption about 'yang based generated
CLI", which is targeted for Phase#2. To me (and I mentioned in the weekly
call as well), one CLI is just one form of the management, there will be
other forms, as well as other CLI models. This infrastructure in the
current PR (application extension) can't assume any specific model. To this
extent, I added a comment to the PR requesting for clarification on a
specific item. Will wait from Stepan.

Thanks
Vissu
